conclusion: The problem involves determining how the shadows (A, B, C, D) of four objects change in position and size when the light source moves to the right above the objects.
The image shows four objects: an egg, an apple, a baseball, and a microphone, each casting shadows on the ground.
Shadow A (egg) moves to the left on the ground as the light source shifts to the right.
Shadow A (egg) grows slightly in size because the light is farther sideways from the egg’s vertical line, lengthening the projection distance.
Shadow B (apple) moves to the left on the ground, drifting more than shadow A because the apple is higher above the ground.
Shadow B (apple) enlarges slightly more than shadow A due to greater sideways displacement increasing shadow length.
Shadow C (baseball) shifts left by about the same amount as shadow B because the baseball is at a comparable height.
Shadow C (baseball) becomes slightly larger, similar to shadow B.
Shadow D (microphone) moves left, with the head’s shadow shifting left and the shaft’s far end detaching more from the head’s shadow, pointing farther left/down-left.
Shadow D (microphone) rotates slightly as the silhouette slides left.
Shadow D (microphone) lengthens the most, especially its shaft, because lateral shifts in the lamp exaggerate the length of a long object tilted toward the ground.
When the light source moves to the right, rays reach objects from a steeper rightward angle, causing shadows to slide left.

The higher an object’s point above the ground or the farther a piece extends sideways from the point touching the ray, the more a small horizontal lamp shift magnifies the horizontal reach of its shadow.
